text: you
the question for me
as a writer in the beginning was that it
was extraordinary because everything on
the streets had meaning after 9/11 so
he'd look at a fire hydrant for instance
and it seemed intimately connected to
everything the fire hydrant went down
into the pipes which went down into the
city which went down to the World Trade
Center which went up into those people's
lives who had been there I'm not so sure
that we could should lay special claim
to the fact that 9/11 influenced an
artist more than say the troubles in
Northern Ireland or or more or less than
the troubles in Northern Ireland or you
know any sort of spectacular sadness or
any spectacular incident in history I
mean it happened and therefore it
continually happens and therefore we
have to react to it I mean an artist
does not have to respond to 911 an
artist doesn't have any responsibility
except to his or her canvas or her
characters and they can be of any ilk I
don't ask people to make pronouncements
in fact pronouncements are completely
uninteresting in general pronouncements
are for politicians I think and you know
as a writer what you want to do is get
in and talk about recovery and talk
about grace and talk about you know the
sadness that would that was there as
well my father-in-law was in the first
building to be hit the second building
to come down he got out when my
father-in-law came home and my daughter
jumped up into his arms and said you
know she thought that he was burning
cause she could smell the smoke come in
coming off his clothes and and and and
then she said well he was burning from
the inside out
and it was like a you know she was four
years old at the time the day the moment
she said that I knew that eventually
someday I would be trying to make sense
of that that that particular feeling I
would never I would never have written
let the great world spin and unless 9/11
had happened em you know shortly after
9/11 I was I was looking around thinking
about how eventually I would I would
write about this and I read Paul
Auster's
essay about Philippe Petit the tightrope
walker who went across the World Trade
Center towers in 74 and I thought that's
it that's the way that eventually I will
I will try to make come to terms with
911 by working on this sort of thing as
a metaphor so I would not would not have
written the book about a tightrope
walker going across the World Trade
Center towers unless the towers had come
down because in that magnificent sort of
way and arced puts them back up there
puts people puts the towers back up when
I go down now to to which I don't do
very often downtown to look at the
terrorists I look up and I still sort of
see Philippe Petit in the air obviously
he did at once and he's gone but a
memory and imagination sort of collide
with one another and and you can put
those towers back up in the air and I
think that's sort of the duty or the
function or the beauty of art
